{{Infobox person | name = Rainer Rene Graf Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1948 | birth_place = [[Wartaweil]], [[Bavaria]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Germany|German]] | other_names = Rene Freiherr von Godin | known_for = Founder of the Federation of German mercenaries | occupation = [[Lawyer]] | criminal_charge = Trafficking of asylum seekers | criminal_penalty = 15 month probation | spouse = Michaela Gräfin Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden | children = Ten }} '''Rainer Rene Graf Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden''' (born '''Rene Freiherr von Godin''',<ref name="Roots" />1948) is a former [[Germany|German]] [[lawyer]] best known for founding the ''Bund deutscher Legionäre'' ({{lang-en|Federation of German mercenaries}}), the ''Christliche Vereinigung zur Familienförderung'' (''English:Christian association for family development''), an agency dealing with the [[adoption]] of [[unborn babies]] and a business in dealing with [[organ donation]]s.<ref name="Spiegel" >[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-13514059.html SÖLDNER - Killen lernen] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', published: 7 October 1985, accessed: 21 November 2010</ref><ref name="Zeit">[http://www.zeit.de/1988/40/Trubel-im-Organbuero Trubel im Organbüro] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008120330/http://www.zeit.de/1988/40/Trubel-im-Organbuero |date=2012-10-08 }} {{de icon}} ''[[Die Zeit]]'', published: 30 September 1988, accessed: 21 November 2010</ref> He also operated a number of other business entities, like the ''Der Wettbewerbsbeobachter'' (''English:The competition monitor'') and the ''Zentralkomitee für die Allgemeinbefolgung obergerichtlicher Rechtssprechung in Wettbewerbssachen'', both targeting small businesses who made small clerical errors in advertisement by "fining" them or taking them to court for violating [[Competition law]].<ref name="Herkunft" >[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-14023531.html AFFÄREN - Neue Herkunft] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', published: 28 February 1983, accessed: 21 November 2010</ref>
After failing his training as [[Catholic Church|catholic]] [[Deacon]] because he had been a member of the youth organisation of the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]],<ref name="Herkunft" /> Adelman formed his own church, the ''Erzbistum München der heiligen katholischen orthodoxen evangelischen Kirche des heiligen Apostels Matthäus'' (English:''Archbishopric of Munich of the holy catholic orthodox church of the [[Apostle (Christian)|apostle]] [[Saint Matthew|Matthew]]'') and awarded offices within the church. He also operated a [[funeral]] business for a time.<ref name="Herkunft" /> Additionally, he ventured into the business of trafficking [[Refugee|asylum seekers]] to Germany, proposing to combine the former with his organ donor business if the asylum seekers were unable to pay.<ref name="Zeit" /><ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-13495310.html Viel Geld für eine Affenfahrt] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', published: 22 May 1989, accessed: 21 November 2010</ref>
It was for his role in the trafficking of asylum seekers and providing them with false papers that he was sent to 15 month in jail on probation in 1992.<ref>[http://www.abendblatt.de/archiv/article.php?xmlurl=http%3a%2f%2farchiv.abendblatt.de%2fha%2f1992%2fxml%2f19921126xml%2fhabxml921012_9910.xml&pdfurl=http%3a%2f%2farchiv.abendblatt.de%2fha%2f1992%2fpdf%2f19921126.pdf%2fASV_HAB_19921126_HA_040.pdf Graf verurteilt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228104617/http://www.abendblatt.de/archiv/article.php?xmlurl=http%3A%2F%2Farchiv.abendblatt.de%2Fha%2F1992%2Fxml%2F19921126xml%2Fhabxml921012_9910.xml&pdfurl=http%3A%2F%2Farchiv.abendblatt.de%2Fha%2F1992%2Fpdf%2F19921126.pdf%2FASV_HAB_19921126_HA_040.pdf |date=2014-02-28 }} {{de icon}} ''[[Hamburger Abendblatt]]'' (subscription required to access full text), published: 26 November 1992, accessed: 22 November 2010</ref> When his house was searched by the police in 1987 in connection to the trafficking of asylum seekers, it was the 14th time that the police had done so in just a few years.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-13525624.html Funktioniert prima] {{de icon}} ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', published: 29 June 1987, accessed: 16 September 2011</ref> German newspaper ''[[Die Zeit]]'' described his reputation as a "businessman without scruple". He was mainly active in the 1980s and, during that time, attracted media attention, but has not done so since his conviction in 1992.<ref name="Zeit" /> By his own description, Graf Adelmann is a "man with many ideas".<ref name="Spiegel" />
==Biography== Rainer Rene Graf Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden was born under the name Rene Freiherr von Godin as the son of a [[Bavaria]]n lawyer in 1948. He married Michaela Gräfin Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden (born 1953) in 1973 and the couple had ten children, born between 1974 and 1988. His wife is the niece of the late German federal [[Member of Parliament|MP]] (1957–1961) [[Raban Graf Adelmann]] (1912–1992).<ref name="Roots">[http://worldroots.com/brigitte/theroff/adelmann.htm Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614055310/http://worldroots.com/brigitte/theroff/adelmann.htm |date=2011-06-14 }} {{de icon}} worldroots.com, accessed: 22 November 2010</ref> Rene Freiherr von Godin assumed the title Graf Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden in 1980. During the mid-1980s, the couple resided in the village of [[Sentenhart]], near [[Wald, Baden-Württemberg|Wald]], between [[Lake Constance]] and [[Sigmaringen]].<ref name="Spiegel" />
The Bavarian ministry of justice cancelled Graf Adelmann's registration as a lawyer in the state in 1982 for discrediting acts unworthy of a lawyer, however, Adelman took the case to the ''[[Bundesgerichtshof]]'' but eventually decided to discontinue his registration himself.<ref name="Zeit" /><ref name="Herkunft" />
==Federation of German mercenaries== Graf Adelmann, in the early 1980s, founded the ''Federation of German mercenaries'' for the purpose of recruiting mercenaries in Germany for service in Asian and African countries.<ref name="Spiegel" />
German law prohibits the recruitment of German citizens for military service in foreign countries and the very attempt is punishable with up to five years of jail. However, Graf Adelmann considered this law invalid as it, in his opinion, violates the freedom of employment specified in the [[German constitution]].<ref name="Spiegel" />
He operated his business through the company ''Terfina Vermögensverwaltungs-GmbH'', and contacted foreign, mainly Asian and African embassies and governments for the purpose of building a clientele. By 1985, Graf Adelmann had over 400 job applications, targeting former ''[[Bundeswehr]]'' soldiers and unemployed adventurers through newspaper ads. In 1985, he claimed to have received interest from an undisclosed African country for the purpose of protecting an oil pipeline.<ref name="Spiegel" />
He also claimed to have interests from [[Mozambique]] to provide personnel for the protection of the [[Cahora Bassa Dam]]. He saw an opportunity to provide personnel to developing countries who still "required adjustments to their borders and forms of government" but lacked qualified personnel to operate their modern weapons equipment. His initial plan was to recruit a [[platoon]] of 50 mercenaries, led by a number of retired ''Bundeswehr'' [[sergeant]]s.<ref name="Spiegel" />
To join the ''Bund deutscher Legionäre'', BDL, one had to pay [[German mark|DM]] 20 as a joining fee, followed by another DM 20 as a yearly membership fee. For this, Graf Adelmann promised combat training in [[Belgium]] and shooting practise in [[Switzerland]], at the weapons manufacturers premises. His new recruits would have to "learn to kill" but he saw great potential in 18-year-olds in this regard. He also guaranteed that the bodies of fallen "heroes" would be returned to Germany and their memory adequately honoured.<ref name="Spiegel" />
==Christian association for family development== Another business Graf Adelmann operated was the ''Christian association for family development'', targeted at childless parents who were interested in adopting an as yet unborn or unconceived, baby. The association was officially shut down in the mid-1980s but continued to operate nevertheless. Adelman charged up to DM 32,000 for a successful adoption, with part of this money going to the mother of the child. The [[Prosecutors Office]] at [[Konstanz]] investigated against the business but was unable to prosecute as it violated no existing law at the time, declaring Adelmann had found a loop hole.<ref name="Spiegel" /><ref name="Herkunft" />
He later opened an agency for adoption in [[Frankfurt am Main]] in early 1988 but had to close after the mayor of the city ordered it shut down.<ref name="Zeit" /> The business suffered a temporary setback when his aunt was arrested in [[Manila]] for [[kidnapping]] but later released.<ref name="Zeit" />
==Organ donation business== In the business of organ donations, Graf Adelmann would approach people who recently had to declare [[bankruptcy]], as published in the [[Bundesanzeiger]], a federal publication, and offered to help them to financial recovery by paying up to DM 80,000 for a [[kidney]], depending on the quality of the organ. Surgery would then be performed in [[France]], Adelman claiming that organ donation for money being legal there despite the fact that both French and German doctors had voluntarily outlawed such transactions. In France however at the time, donations from live donors were acceptable, providing no money was involved. Graf Adelmann just simply would keep the full truth from the performing clinic and thereby was able to carry out his business.<ref name="Zeit" /><ref>[http://www.organselling.com/document.htm Organ Selling] organselling.com, accessed: 21 November 2010</ref> Graf Adelmann later declared that no operations were carried out. In 1989, he tried to expand his business to the [[United Kingdom]] and was able to find a number of willing donors there, offering between US$30,000 and 50,000 per kidney, with the intention of making a 20% cut on every operation. The willing donors never heard from Graf Adelmann again after the initial contact. Shortly after, the [[British Parliament]] banned the sale of human organs for the purpose of transplants.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/01/science/sales-of-kidneys-prompt-new-laws-and-debate.html?pagewanted=all Sales of Kidneys Prompt New Laws and Debate] ''[[The New York Times]]'', published: 1 August 1989, accessed; 21 November 2010</ref>
Graf Adelmann's activities even prompted a request in the German Parliament, the ''[[Bundestag]]'', in 1989, to tighten the organ donor law in the country and to shorten the lengthy donation process. A number of MP's of the Social Democratic Party of Germany posted the question what the federal government would do against Adelmann's activities.<ref> [http://dipbt.bundestag.de/dip21/btd/11/051/1105199.pdf Verbesserung der Voraussetzung für Organverpflanzungen] {{de icon}} ''[[Bundestag]]'' website, published: 18 September 1989, accessed: 21 November 2010</ref>
==Name and title== {{German title Graf}} {{German title Freiherr}} As royalty and its privileges have been abolished in Germany, the Name "Graf Adelmann von Adelmannsfelden" is one complex family name only and not a family name and a title. The part of "Graf" in this family name is only a part of this family name and not a legally valid title.

[[File:Rodin alper bingöl.jpg|thumb|Rodin Alper Bingöl]] {{Infobox person | name = Rodin Alper Bingöl | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1984|05|22}} | birth_place = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | death_date = | spouse = | children = | nationality = [[Turkish people|Turkish]] | other_names = | known_for = Column, Interviews | alma_mater = [[Istanbul Bilgi University]]
Visual Communication Design | occupation = Creative Director
Entrepreneur
Head of Agency
Founder of the RBM (Removing Barriers Movement) | website = [http://rodinalper.com rodinalper.com] }} '''Rodin Alper Bingöl''' (May 22, 1984), is a [[Turkish people|Turkish]] [[creative director]], [[entrepreneur]] and business leader known with his works in [[advertisement]], [[design]], digital campaigns and [[social responsibility]]. ==Biography== Bingöl was born in Istanbul in 1984. He had his first digital experiences in 1996 while he was building amateur web sites and web platforms which were the pioneers of the internet industry in Turkey. During his years in high school, becoming interested in acting, he took acting classes at the Stage of Kadıköy Public Training Center for two years. In 2002, he graduated from the mechanical department of the Haydarpaşa Anatolian Technical High School. He worked as a designer and instructor at the Bilge Adam Computer Education Center in his last year at high school. Excelling at his business life by becoming an art director, he decided to leave the Center in 2003. He continued his education at the Faculty of Visual Communication Design at the [[İstanbul Bilgi University]]. In his first year, he established Colors of Bilgi, one of the most active and efficient student clubs of the [[İstanbul Bilgi University]]. As the general coordinator and the art director of the magazine published by the Club, he organized photo shoots and interviews with public figures such as [[Cem Yılmaz]], [[Serdar Erener]], [[Metin Arolat]] ve [[Ali Nesin]] and got the chance to use his passion for photography. As the first student from the Faculty of Communication who participated in the elections, he was the leader and the creative director of the advertising campaigns of the team “Bilgistanbul” in the 2007 Student Union Elections.{{cite web|title = Sen Sor Rodin Alper Bingöl Yanıtlasın |url= http://www.onedergi.com/2010/04/sen-sor-rodin-alper-bingol-yanitlasin/|website=Onedergi.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}} Between 2004 and 2006 he cofounded Colors of USA, the first online [[Work and Travel]] firm in Turkey. He traveled to many countries, including United States of America, England and Mexico for business and marketing purposes. Besides his education, he took part in many different projects as the art and project director. He worked with artists such as [[Tarkan (singer)|Tarkan]], [[Cem Yılmaz]], [[Çağan Irmak]] and [[Zeki Demirkubuz]]; he designed and executed web sites, movie posters and advertising campaigns by creating unique concepts. He contributed to the projects of some of the biggest companies including Swiss Hotel, Bilge Adam, Aviva, [[TÜPRAŞ]] and [[Ülker]]. The official movie posters for [[Çağan Irmak]]’s [[Issız Adam]], [[Zeki Demirkubuz]]’s [[Envy (2009 film) Envy]] and [[Tuna Kiremitçi]]’s [[Adını Sen Koy]] were some of the creative works done by Bingöl in this period of time.{{cite web|title = Rodin Alper Bingöl's IMDb Title |url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3648099/|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}} While he was still a student, he gave lectures at the Marmara University in the 2008-2009 academic year, focusing on Digital Marketing and Media Technologies. Described as a “Young Talent” by various media organizations, Bingöl gave interviews to widely read magazines such as Trensetter, Marketing Türkiye, Boxer and Cosmogirl.{{cite web|title = Engelleri Kaldır Hareketiyle Fark Yaratan Rodin Alper Bingöl |url= http://www.sabancivakfi.org/haber/engelleri-kaldir-hareketiyle-fark-yaratan-rodin-alper-bingol|website=Sabancivakfi.org|accessdate=24 September 2012}} He graduated from the [[İstanbul Bilgi University]] in 2009 by setting up and executing a social responsibility project, [[Removing Barriers Movement]] as his thesis. The project gathered a lot of public attention. Celebrities including [[Ahmet Mümtaz Taylan]], [[Ali Poyrazoğlu]], [[Ali Sunal]], Aslıgül Atasagun, [[Ayçin İnci]], [[Ayşenur Yazıcı]], [[Barış Falay]], [[Bengü]], [[Bora Cengiz]], [[Burcu Kara]], [[Bülent Şakrak]], [[Doğa Rutkay]], [[Ebru Akel]], [[Emre Altuğ]], [[Erdem Yener]], [[Hayko Cepkin]], [[Lale Mansur]], [[Mert Fırat]], [[Mustafa Üstündağ]], [[Müşfik Kenter]], Özge Uzun, Pit10, [[Saba Tümer]], [[Taner Birsel]], [[Tülin Özen]], [[Yetkin Dikinciler]] acted voluntarily in the promotional clips of the Project.{{cite web|title = EKH – 1 Nisan Farkındalık Kampanyası |url= http://www.engellerikaldir.com/projeler/kampanyalar/1-nisan-farkindalik-kampanyasi|website=Engellerikaldir.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}}{{cite web|title = Turkey's Changemakers: Rodin Alper Bingol campaigns to help people with disabilities participate in social life |url= http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=turkeys-changemakers-rodin-alper-bingol-campaigns-to-help-people-with-disabilities-participate-2010-03-15|website=Hurriyetdailynews.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}} In addition to his prior achievements, he was awarded first place by JCI Turkey at the “Turkey’s The Most Successful Young Persons of the Year Contest”.{{cite web|title = Web World Gets 4 Awards from Turkey’s The Most Successful Young Persons of the Year Contest |url= http://en.webrazzi.com/2009/10/20/in-turkey%E2%80%99s-must-successful-10-young-persons-contest-web-world-gets-4-awards/|website=En.webrazzi.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}}{{cite web|title = 2010 Yılı Empati Ödülü Sahibini Buldu |url= http://www.aktuelegitim.com/2010-yili-empati-odulu-sahibini-buldu.html|website=Aktuelegitim.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}} [[Fark Yaratanlar]], [[CNN Türk]]’s TV show which is hosted by [[Cüneyt Özdemir]], defined Bingöl as “a real hero”.{{cite web|title = Turkey's Changemakers - Rodin Alper Bingol |url= http://www.sabancivakfi.org/media/rodin-alper-bingol-sezon-01-bolum-22-2|website=Sabancivakfi.org|accessdate=24 September 2012}} In 2009, with the help of his former business experiences, he founded [[Elmalma Brand Communication]]. As the creative director and the manager of the Agency, he developed many projects contributing to the progress of the digital opportunities and efficient use of the social media both in Turkey and the World. Along with artists such as [[Cem Yılmaz]], [[Murat Boz]], [[Demet Akalın]], [[Yılmaz Erdoğan]], [[Ömer Faruk Sorak]] Bingöl provided digital solutions for corporate brands including [[Fida Film]], [[Böcek Yapım]], Saran Holding, [[LTB]], [[Show TV]] {{cite web|title = Cem Yılmaz’ın Adı Twitter’a Yetiyor |url= http://gundem.milliyet.com.tr/cem-yilmaz-in-adi-twitter-a-yetiyor/gundem/gundemdetay/12.01.2012/1487948/default.htm |website=Milliyet.com.tr|accessdate=24 September 2012}} In July 2011, [[Elmalma Brand Communication]] teamed up with [[Böcek Yapım]] which is run by the director [[Ömer Faruk Sorak]] and Oğuz Peri.{{cite web|title=Elmalma – Marka Psikoloğu|url=http://elmalma.com/tr/markaPsikologu/|website=Elmalma.com|accessdate=24 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922044549/http://elmalma.com/tr/markaPsikologu|archivedate=22 September 2012|df=}} ==Awards== {| class="wikitable" ! style="background:#efefef;" | Year ! style="background:#efefef;" | Institution ! style="background:#efefef;" | Award |- | 2009 | Junior Chamber Turkey | TOYP ’09 (Ten Outstanding Young Persons) - Contribution to Human Rights, Children and World Peace – First Place |- | 2010 | [[Turkish Psychological Counseling and Guidance Association]] | Empathy Award of the Year |- | 2010 | [[Justice Academy of Turkey]] | Social Contribution Award |} ==See also== *[[Removing Barriers Movement]] *[[Elmalma Brand Communication]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.rodinalper.com Personal web site: rodinalper.com] * [http://www.dusunenadam.org Personal blog: dusunenadam.org] * [https://twitter.com/rodinAlper Official Twitter: twitter.com/rodinalper] * [http://elmalma.com Elmalma Brand Communication] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bingol, Rodin Alper}} [[Category:Graphic designers]] [[Category:Turkish designers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Poster artists]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2013}} A '''tax advisor''' or '''tax consultant''' is a person with advanced training and knowledge of [[tax law]]. The services of a tax advisor are usually retained in order to minimize taxation while remaining compliant with the law in complicated financial situations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/taxadvisor.asp|title=Tax Advisor Definition|publisher=Investopedia|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> Tax Advisors are also retained to represent clients before tax authorities and tax courts to resolve tax issues.
==World== ===Austria=== In [[Austria]], Steuerberater is the professional license for tax advisors.
===Germany=== {{See also|Steuerberater}} In [[Germany]], Steuerberater is the professional license for tax advisors.<ref name=bstbk>{{cite web|url=http://www.bstbk.de/de/index.html|title=Bundessteuerberaterkammer|publisher=Bundessteuerberaterkammer|language=German|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref>
===Italy=== In [[Italy]], tax advisors are called ''commercialisti'', and provide assistance on [[business management]], [[business law]], [[economics]], [[finance]], tax, [[accounting]], commercial, corporate and administrative matters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/growth/tools-databases/regprof/index.cfm?action=regprof&id_regprof=18165&cookies=disabled|title=Dottore commercialista (Italy)|publisher=[[European Commission]]|access-date=19 July 2017}}</ref><ref>Treccani, [http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/commercialista/ commercialista]</ref> ''Dottori commercialisti'', who have a degree in [[economics]], and ''ragionieri commercialisti'', who have a [[diploma]] from an ''[[istituto tecnico economico]]'', were members of two different [[Professional Order|professional orders]], but they were merged in 2008 and it is now impossible to become a ''commercialista'' without a ''[[Laurea#Second cycle: Laurea Magistrale|laurea magistrale]]''. ''Esperti contabili'', whose roles are similar to those of a ''commercialista'', must have a ''[[Laurea#First cycle: Laurea|laurea]]'', a first cycle degree that is equivalent to a [[bachelor's degree]]. According to the Italian law, the following activities are some of the roles of a ''commercialista'': * the administration and liquidation of companies and assets; * surveys and technical advice; * inspections and administrative reviews; * verifications and investigations regarding the reliability of [[financial statements]], [[financial accounts|accounts]] and records of a [[company]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lavoroeformazione.it/1/lavoro/il-dottore-commercialista-,138|title=Il dottore commercialista|publisher=lavoroeformazione.it|language=Italian|access-date=19 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unive.it/pag/10159/|title=Dottore commercialista, Esperto contabile, Revisore legale|publisher=[[Ca' Foscari University of Venice]]|language=Italian|access-date=19 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elenco-commercialisti.it/dottore-commercialista.html|title=Dottore commercialista e ragioniere commercialista|publisher=ItaliaWeb Srl|language=Italian||access-date=19 July 2017}}</ref>
===Japan=== In [[Japan]], there is a specific license for tax advisors called {{nihongo|'''certified public tax accountant'''|税理士|zeirishi}}. In order to obtain this qualification, an individual must pass a special state examination, or already be qualified as an [[attorney at law (Japan)|attorney at law]] or [[certified public accountant]].<ref>[http://www.nichizeiren.or.jp/eng/index.html Japan Federation of Certified Public Tax Accountants' Organizations]</ref>
===South Korea=== In [[South Korea]], there is a specific license for tax advisors called '''certified tax accountant'''. In order to obtain this qualification, an individual must pass a special examination.
===United Kingdom=== In the [[United Kingdom|UK]], guidelines concerning professional conduct in relation to taxation are published in conjunction with the [[Chartered Institute of Taxation]], the [[Association of Taxation Technicians]], the [[Institute of Indirect Taxation]], the [[Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales]], the [[Institute of Chartered Accountants of Scotland]] and the [[Association of Chartered Certified Accountants]]. These were prepared for the assistance of members of the various associations both generally in dealing with clients and the tax authorities and specifically in relation to irregularities and errors.
The guidelines, which include practical advice about a range of legal and ethical issues, are summarised as:
* A member's primary duty is to ensure that his actions comply with the law. He/she owes a contractual duty to the client to act for him/her with the requisite degree of skill and care, and the contractual relationship should be governed by a letter of engagement. The member also has duties to the tax authorities, notably of compliance with the law and the honest presentation of his client's circumstances. * It is the taxpayer's responsibility to ensure that returns made to the tax authorities are correct and complete. It is for the member to assist him to decide on the extent and manner of disclosure of facts in relation to his tax affairs. *Where a member becomes aware that irregularities have occurred in relation to a client's tax affairs he should advise the client of the consequences, and the manner of disclosure. If necessary, appropriate specialist advice should be taken. * Where a client refuses to follow the advice of a member in relation to issues involving disclosure, the member should consider whether he should continue to act. If appropriate, specialist advice should be taken. * If mistakes are made by the tax authorities there may be a need, and in some cases a duty, on the part of the client and sometimes the member, to put matters right. * Members may have statutory duties of disclosure where they have suspicions of criminal activity. * When approached for information on a client's affairs by another adviser the member should ensure that he has his client's authority before making any disclosure.
===United States=== In the United States, paid tax return preparers are regulated but not licensed by the [[Internal Revenue Service]] of the [[United States Department of the Treasury]]. There are penalties for failure to disclose the identity of the preparer on the return, for the failure to give the taxpayer a copy of the return, and for negligence in preparing the return.
Practice before the Internal Revenue Service is regulated by [[Circular 230|''Treasury Department Circular No. 230'']], ''Regulations Governing the Practice of Attorneys, Certified Public Accountants, Enrolled Agents, Enrolled Actuaries, and Appraisers before the Internal Revenue Service''.<ref>Codified in regulations at 31 C.F.R. subtitle A, part 10.</ref> Most practice is limited to [[Attorney at law (United States)|attorneys]], [[Certified Public Accountant]]s (CPAs), [[enrolled agent]]s, and [[enrolled actuary|enrolled actuaries]]. Rendering tax advice is also regulated by [[Circular 230]].
Failure to uphold these standards can result in disciplinary action ranging from reprimand to permanent disbarrment from practice.
In the United States, the term "tax professional" is a generic term describing a variety of professions including enrolled agents, Certified Public Accountants (CPAs), [[financial planner]]s, [[accountant]]s, [[tax preparer]]s, and some [[lawyer]]s.
In the United States, by far the largest segment of tax professionals are individual tax preparers. *[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/31/330.html 31 U.S.C. § 330] *[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/5/500.html 5 U.S.C. § 500. ]
== See also == *[[Tax avoidance]] *[[Tax evasion]] *[[Taxation in Germany]] *[[Worshipful Company of Tax Advisers]] ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use Indian English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Tech Mahindra Ltd. | logo = [[File:Tech Mahindra New Logo.svg|200px]] | type = [[public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{Unbulleted list|{{BSE|532755}}|{{NSE|TECHM}}}} | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|[[Anand Mahindra]] {{Small|(Chairman & Founder)}}|[[Vineet Nayyar]] {{Small|(VC)}}|[[CP Gurnani]] {{Small|(CEO)}}}} | industry = [[IT service management|IT services]], [[Information technology consulting|IT consulting]] | services = [[IT]], [[business consulting]] and [[outsourcing]] | revenue = {{profit}} [[US$]]4.77 billion (2018)<ref name=2018res/> | net_income = {{profit}} [[US$]]588 million (2018)<ref name=2018res/> | num_employees = 113,550+ (2018 Q1)<ref name=2018res>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techmahindra.com/sites/resourceCenter/Financial%20Reports/Q4-FY18-Factsheet.pdf|title=Tech Mahindra Limited Consolidated Fact Sheet Data|publisher=Tech Mahindra}}</ref> | parent = [[Mahindra Group]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1986}} | location = [[Pune]], [[India]]<ref>[http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra Satyam is history: Mahindra Group merges Satyam with Tech Mahindra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115033608/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra |date=15 January 2016 }}</ref> | homepage = {{URL|http://www.techmahindra.com/}} }}
'''Tech Mahindra Limited'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instafinancials.com/company/tech-mahindra-limited/L64200MH1986PLC041370 |title=Tech Mahindra Limited |website=instafinancials.com |date= |accessdate=2018-11-25}}</ref> is an [[India]]n<nowiki/> [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] provider of [[information technology]] (IT), networking technology [[solution]]s and [[Business process outsourcing|Business Process Outsourcing]] (BPO) to various industry verticals and horizontals. [[Anand Mahindra]] is the Chairman of Tech Mahindra, which is headquartered at [[Pune]] and has its registered office in [[Mumbai]].
Part of the [[Mahindra Group]], Tech Mahindra is a {{USD}}4.7 billion company<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/company/default.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra|website=techmahindra.com|publisher=TechMahindra|accessdate=January 1, 2018}}</ref> with over 113,550 employees across 90 countries.<ref name=2018res/> Tech Mahindra was ranked #5 in India's software services (IT) firms and overall #111 in [[Fortune India 500]] list for 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://financeshop.capitalmarket.com/compendium/rankingcompendium.htm|title= Ranking of Top 500 Companies}}</ref> Tech Mahindra, on 25 June 2013, announced the completion of a merger with [[Mahindra Satyam]].<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/185-swap-for-tech-mahindra-mahindra-satyam-merger/article4849296.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=1:8.5 swap for Tech Mahindra, Mahindra Satyam merger | date=June 25, 2013}}</ref>
Tech Mahindra has 926 active clients as of March 2018.<ref name=2018res/>
==History== ===Foundation=== [[Mahindra & Mahindra]] started a joint venture with [[British Telecom]] in 1986 as a technology outsourcing firm. British Telecom initially had around 30 percent stake in the Tech Mahindra company. In December 2010, British Telecom sold 5.5 per cent of its stake in Tech Mahindra to Mahindra & Mahindra for Rs 451 crore.<ref>{{cite web|title=BT Group to exit from Tech Mahindra, directors resign|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-12-24/news/30554758_1_bt-group-tech-mahindra-techm|publisher=Economic Times|accessdate=4 July 2015|date=24 December 2011}}</ref> In August 2012, British Telecom sold 14.1 per cent of its stake to institutional investors for about Rs 1,395 crore. In December 2012, British Telecom sold its remaining 9.1 per cent (11.6 million shares) shareholding to institutional investors for a total gross cash proceeds of Rs 1,011.4 crore. This sale marked the exit of British Telecom from Tech Mahindra.<ref>{{cite web|title=BT exits Tech Mahindra|url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/companies/bt-exits-tech-mahindra/article4191751.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=4 July 2015|date=12 December 2012}}</ref>
===Acquisition of Satyam Computer Services Ltd.=== After the [[Satyam scandal]] of 2008-09 Tech Mahindra bid for [[Satyam Computer Services]], and emerged as a top bidder with an offer of Rs 58.90 a share for a 31 per cent stake in the company, beating a strong rival [[Larsen & Toubro]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/tech-mahindra-wins-satyam-bid--full-coverage/90124-7.html|title=Tech Mahindra wins Satyam Computer bid|work=IBNLive}}</ref> After evaluating the bids, the government-appointed board of Satyam Computer announced on 13 April 2009: "its Board of Directors has selected Venturbay Consultants Private Limited, a subsidiary controlled by Tech Mahindra Limited as the highest bidder to acquire a controlling stake in the Company, subject to the approval of the Hon'ble Company Law Board." Through a subsidiary, it has emerged victorious in [[Mahindra Satyam|Satyam]] sell-off, a company probably two times its size in number of people. This was one of the largest merger deals in India's tech industry.
===Merger with Mahindra Satyam=== [[Image:Anand Mahindra (1).jpg|thumb|right|Mahindra Group V-C [[Anand Mahindra]]]] Tech Mahindra announced its [[Tech Mahindra-Mahindra Satyam merger|merger]] with [[Mahindra Satyam]] on March 21, 2012, after the boards of the two companies gave their approval, to create a 2.5 billion $ IT Company<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-06-21/news/29683399_1_tech-mahindra-mahindra-satyam-mahindra-satyam-tech-mahindra-sixth-largest-software-exporter/|title=Rising wages can harm Indian IT companies: Vineet Nayyar, Vice-Chairman, Tech Mahindra|work=timesofindia-economictimes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/2012/03/21094345/Tech-Mahindra-Satyam-get-nod.html|title=Tech Mahindra, Satyam get nod to merge|publisher=}}</ref> The two firms had received the go-ahead for the merger from the [[Bombay Stock Exchange]] and the [[National Stock Exchange of India|National Stock Exchange]].<ref>[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/info-tech/article3304195.ece/ Mahindra Satyam-TechM to take 150 top leaders to Bangkok] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140315133139/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/info-tech/article3304195.ece/ |date=15 March 2014 }}</ref> On June 11, 2013, Andhra Pradesh High Court gave its approval for the merger of Mahindra Satyam with Tech Mahindra, after the Bombay high court had already given its approval.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-11/software-services/39898413_1_mahindra-satyam-tech-mahindra-merger | work=The Times Of India | title=Mahindra Satyam, Tech Mahindra merger gets AP High Court's nod — The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/andhra-pradesh-high-court-clears-merger-of-mahindra-satyam-with-tech-mahindra/articleshow/20538518.cms | work=The Times Of India | title=Andhra Pradesh High Court clears merger of Mahindra Satyam with Tech Mahindra | date=June 11, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| Gurnani]] as the CEO and Managing Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/m-satyam-tech-mahindra-hope-to-merge-in-four-weeks/1/279629.html|title=M-Satyam, Tech Mahindra hope to merge in four weeks|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/will-complete-tech-mah-satyam-merger8-weeks-nayyar-_896218.html|title=Will complete Tech Mah, Satyam merger in 8 weeks: Nayyar|date=11 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/high-court-clears-merger-of-mahindra-satyam-with-tech-mahindra/article4803837.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=MSat-Tech Mahindra merger gets court nod | date=June 11, 2013}}</ref> On June 25, 2013, Tech Mahindra announced the completion of its merger with Mahindra Satyam to create the nation's fifth largest software services company with a turnover of USD 2.7 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/companies/mahindra-satyam-merges-with-tech-mahindra_78656.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619224313/http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/companies/mahindra-satyam-merges-with-tech-mahindra_78656.html |archivedate=19 June 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/tech-mahindra-satyam-computer-complete-merger_905059.html|title=Tech Mahindra, Satyam Computer complete merger|date=25 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref> Tech Mahindra got the approval from the registrar of companies for the merger at 11:45 pm on June 24, 2013. July 5, 2013 has been determined as record date on which the Satyam Computer Services ('Mahindra Satyam') shares will be swapped for Tech Mahindra shares under the approved scheme.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115033608/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130626/news-businesstech/article/satyam-history-mahindra-group-merges-satyam-tech-mahindra |archivedate=15 January 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Mahindra Satyam]] (Satyam Computer Services), was suspended from trading with effect from July 4, 2013, following the merger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/market-news/tradingmahindra-satyam-to-be-suspendedjuly-4_908200.html|title=Trading in Mahindra Satyam to be suspended from July 4|date=29 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref> Tech Mahindra completed share swap and allocated its shares to the shareholders of Satyam Computer Services on July 12, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/satyam-is-no-more-to-live-on-as-part-of-tech-mahindra-113071400336_1.html|title=Satyam is no more; to live on as part of Tech Mahindra|author=Press Trust of India|date=14 July 2013|publisher=}}</ref> The stock exchanges have accorded their approval for trading the new shares effective July 12, 2013. Tech Mahindra posted net profit of Rs 686 crore for the first quarter ended June 30, 2013, up 27% compared to the corresponding quarter last year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/business/report/tech-mahindra-completes-share-swap-issued-capital-goes-up/20130712.htm|title=Tech Mahindra completes share swap, issued capital goes up|date=12 July 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Tech-Mahindra-completes-share-swap/articleshow/21044763.cms | work=The Times Of India | title=Tech Mahindra completes share swap — The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/tech-mahindra-q1-net-up-27-y-o-y-113081200500_1.html|title=Tech Mahindra Q1 net up|author=BS Reporter|date=13 August 2013|publisher=}}</ref> By March 2016, Tech Mahindra's post-tax earnings had surged past that of M&M.
==Timeline== * 1986 - Created as a joint venture of [[Mahindra & Mahindra]] and [[British Telecommunications]] (later BT Group).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bcd214ae-f1f6-11e1-8973-00144feabdc0.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002110511/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bcd214ae-f1f6-11e1-8973-00144feabdc0.html|archive-date=2 October 2012|title=BT set to reduce stake in Tech Mahindra|date= 29 Aug 2012|author=Daniel Thomas|quote=BT founded Tech Mahindra as a joint venture with Mahindra & Mahindra, the Indian vehicle group, in 1986.}}</ref> * 1993 - Incorporation of MBT International Inc., the first overseas subsidiary * 1994 - Awarded ISO 9001 certification by [[BVQI]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/company/corporate_history.aspx|title=Corporate History - Tech Mahindra|publisher=}}</ref> * 1995 - Established UK branch office * 2001 - Incorporated MBT GmbH, Germany incorporated. Re-certified to [ISO 9001:1994] by BVQI{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} * 2002 - Assessed at Level 2 of SEI CMM by KPMG. Incorporated MBT Software Technologies Pte. Assessed at Level 3 of SEI CMMI by KPMG * 2006 - Name changed to Tech Mahindra Limited. Assessed at Level 4 of SEI People-CMM (P-CMM) by QAI India. Raised Rs46.5 million ($1 million) from an IPO to build a new facility in Pune, to house about 9,000 staff. Formed a JV with Motorola Inc. under the name CanvasM. * 2007 - Acquired iPolicy Networks Private Limited. Launched the [[Tech Mahindra Foundation]] to help underprivileged people. Assessed at Level 5 of SEI CMMI by KPMG * 2009 - Tech M wins bid for fraud-hit [[Satyam Computer Services]] at Rs 58.90 per share outdoing Larsen & Toubro, which bid at Rs 45.90. Rebrands the company to Mahindra Satyam. * 2012 - Acquires Hutchison Global Services for $87.1 million * 2012 - Buys 51% stake in [[Comviva]] * 2012 - Tech Mahindra acquires vCustomer BPO for $27 million * 2013 - Tech Mahindra acquires Sweden-based Type Approval Lab. The lab was part of Sony Mobile Communication's internal test function and after acquisition it became the first European test lab of Tech Mahindra.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-24/news/38790530_1_comviva-hutchison-global-services-tech-mahindra |title=Tech Mahindra acquires Sweden-based Type Approval Lab |publisher=The Economics Times |date= |accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref> * 2013 - On June 25, Tech Mahindra and [[Mahindra Satyam]] merging process completed and the name of the parent company was retained for the merged entity<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/tech-mahindra-goes-for-growth-by-acquisition-113101500020_1.html|title=Tech Mahindra goes for growth by acquisition|author=Clifford Alvares|date=15 October 2013|publisher=}}</ref> * 2014 - Tech Mahindra acquires Lightbridge Communications Corporation (LCC), the largest independent telecom services company in the world with local presence in over 50 countries. * 2015 - Tech Mahindra acquires SOFGEN Holdings, a 450-employee Swiss IT firm serving the financial services industry<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-01-09/news/57883595_1_tech-mahindra-lightbridge-communications-gurnani|title=?Tech Mahindra to acquire Swiss firm SOFGEN Holdings|work=timesofindia-economictimes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techmahindra.com/media/press_releases/Tech_Mahindra_Augments_Its_Core_Banking_Expertise.aspx|title=Tech Mahindra Augments Its Core Banking Expertise, To acquire SOFGEN Holdings Limited|publisher=}}</ref> * 2015 - news|url=https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/politics/bs-md-alec-ross-profile-20180521-story.html|title=Democrat Alec Ross, tech expert and author, says as Maryland governor he'll focus on 'what's next'|last=Wood|first=Pamela|date=May 24, 2018|work=The Baltimore Sun|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Ross launched a campaign for the Governor of Maryland in 2017.<ref name=":5" /> The book explores the forces that will change the world in robotics, genetics, digital currency, coding and big data.<ref name=":4" />
== Overview == The Industries of the Future by Senior Policy Advisor [[Alec Ross (government official)|Alec Ross]] explores the geopolitical, cultural and generational changes that will be driven by the key industries over the next twenty years. Ross is a Distinguished Visiting Fellow at [[Johns Hopkins University]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://alecross.com/about/|title=Alec Ross - Leading Expert on Innovation|website=Alec Ross {{!}} Technology Policy Expert, Innovator and Author|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref> and was the Senior Advisor for Innovation to [[Hillary Clinton|Secretary of State Hillary Clinton]].<ref name=":2">{{Citation|last=Talks at Google|title=Alec Ross: "The Industries of the Future" {{!}} Talks at Google|date=2016-04-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fMmM2Jtkhxc|accessdate=2016-04-16}}</ref> During his time as Senior Advisor for Innovation he visited forty-one countries looking at the technological advances.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wnyc.org/story/global-economy-come/?hootPostID=d6814599a4be899c06782c2a3f764f5e|title=A Road Map for the Future|website=WNYC|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref> He has been a guest lecturer at a number of institutions including the [[United Nations]], [[University of Oxford]], [[Harvard Law School]], and [[Stanford Graduate School of Business|Stanford Business School]].<ref name=":1" /> Ross started his career as a teacher through Teach for America and in 2000 he co-founded a technology-focused nonprofit organization called [[One Economy Corporation|One Economy]].<ref name=":1" />
The book explores several industries including robotics, genetics, coding and big data. Ross explores how advances in robotics and life sciences will change the way we live—robots, artificial intelligence and machine learning will have impact on our lives. According to Ross, dramatic advances in life sciences will increase our life expectancy—but not all will benefit from such changes. Ross spends time exploring "Code" and how the codefication of money and also weapons (computer security) will both benefit and potentially disrupt our international economies. Ross also looks at how data will be "the raw material of the information age."<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Industries of the Future|last=Ross|first=Alec|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2016|isbn=9781476753652|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Ross also focuses on globalization and geopolitical economics. He explores how competitiveness and how societies, families and individuals will need to thrive.<ref name=":0" /> Ross gives attention to the importance of women stating that "the states and societies that do the most for women are those that will be best positioned to compete and succeed in the industries of the future."<ref name=":0" /> The book also touches on how to prepare children for "success in a world of increasing change and competition."<ref name=":0" />
Ross discusses the shift of robotics from being manual and repetitive to cognitive and non-repetitive.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://searchcio.techtarget.com/feature/Alec-Ross-on-how-cognitive-robots-will-change-the-world|title=Alec Ross on how cognitive robots will change the world|website=SearchCIO|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref> He believes that breakthroughs in [[mathematical model]]ing and [[cloud robotics]] ([[machine learning]] and [[Artificial intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]]) make robotics acceptable.<ref name=":3" /> In the book Ross describes how other cultures have different reactions to robotics and he uses Japan's use of robotics in elder-care as an example.<ref name=":0" /> He also expects that less developed countries may be able to leapfrog technologies in robotics much like they did with cell and mobile technologies.<ref name=":0" />
According to Ross, the last trillion dollar industry was created out of computer code; the next trillion dollar industry will be created out of genome code.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/videos/tv/2016/02/16/exp-gps-0214-alec-ross-interview.cnn|title=Ross on the future of work - CNN Video|website=CNN|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dawn-nakagawa/alec-ross--genetic-code_b_9146928.html|title=The Next Trillion-Dollar Industry Could Be Built on Genetic Code|date=2016-02-04|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref> In the book Ross describes how [[genome]] code is already being used to fix humans from curing [[cancer]] to hacking the brain to growing organs. He also describes the difference between the [[United States]] investment in genome research with that of [[China]].<ref name=":0" />
Ross then turns to the "code-ification" of money, markets and trust. He describes the transition from cash to mobile and online banking. He also discusses the sharing economy from eBay to AirBnB and then gives an overview of BitCoin and blockchain technology.<ref name=":0" /> Ross also focuses on [[Computer security|cybersecurity]] and the weaponization of code with a focus on a move from cold war to "code war." Ross states that he expects the total market size of the cyberindustry to reach $175 billion by the end of 2017.<ref name=":0" />
== Development history == Alec Ross has said that he intended to give a balanced point of view with the book that it is neither a [[Utopia]]n or [[Dystopia]]n vision of the future which is why he opened the book with the struggles he witnessed growing up in West Virginia.<ref name=":2" /> On writing the book Ross said that he knows his parents would have wanted a book like this in the sixties that would describe what globalization would do and he wished that he had a book like this when he graduated from college that would have explored the Internet and digitization on the economy.<ref name=":0" />
The editors for the book were Jonathan Karp and Jonathan Cox of [[Simon & Schuster]].<ref name=":0" />
== Reviews and reception == ''The Industries of the Future'' has received mainly positive reviews from the likes of ''[[Forbes]]'', ''New York Journal of Books'', and ''[[Financial Times]]''. ''Forbes'' contributor Peter Decherney said the book "reads like a portable [[TED (conference)|TED conference]] at which you've been seated next to the smartest guy in the room."<ref name="Decherney">{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterdecherney/2016/01/30/a-bad-time-to-be-a-control-freak-alec-ross-forecasts-the-industries-of-the-future/#575ae045209c|title=Searching for the Next Silicon Valley: Alec Ross Forecasts the Industries of the Future|last=Decherney|first=Peter|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref> The book was also listed on the Forbes list—''16 New Books for Leaders to Begin in 2016''.<ref name="Decherney"/> [[Tara Sonenshine|Tara D. Sonenshine]] in the ''New York Journal of Books'' called the book a good place to start "if you want to know how to survive and thrive in the fast-paced world of today and how to anticipate the opportunities of tomorrow's information age." Sonenshine also called out the book for focusing on women and multiculturalism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nyjournalofbooks.com/book-review/industries-future|title=a book review by Tara Sonenshine: The Industries of the Future|website=www.nyjournalofbooks.com|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref> In an article titled "Is predicting the future futile or necessary?" by Stephen Cave in the ''Financial Times'' is more critical, saying that Ross focuses on industries with already considerable coverage and investment but Cave points out that "rarely can the future be predicted by extending current trajectories."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/5815c14a-b2e7-11e5-b147-e5e5bba42e51.html|title=Is predicting the future futile or necessary?|last=Cave|first=Stephen|date=2016-01-08|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-04-16}}</ref>
== Trends == The following trends are covered in the book:<ref name=":0" /> * [[Robotics]]<ref name=":0" /> * Advanced [[Life Sciences]]<ref name=":0" /> * Code-ification of Money<ref name=":0" /> * [[Computer security|Cybersecurity]]<ref name=":0" /> * [[Big data|Big Data]]<ref name=":0" />

'''Thomas Finney''' (1837–1903) was an [[Australia]]n businessman and politician. He represented the [[electoral district of Toowong]] in the [[Legislative Assembly of Queensland]] from 1896 until 1900.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A040182b.htm|title=Finney, Thomas (1837-1903)|author=A.A. Morrison|year=1972|accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref><ref name=qp>{{cite web|title=Former Members|publisher=[[Parliament of Queensland]]|year=2015| url=http://www.parliament.qld.gov.au/members/former/bio?id=2006432948|accessdate= 26 January 2015}}</ref>
==Biography== Thomas Finney was born 10 January 1837<ref>http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/finney-thomas-3518</ref> at Currakeen House, [[Tuam]], [[Galway]], [[Ireland]]. His father was Thomas Finney and his mother was Eliza Finney, née Cornwall. He began work at a drapery shop in 1856, and in 1862 emigrated to [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]] with his partner James Isles.
The two started a drapery business, Finney Isles & Co., which was extremely successful. In 1869 the company had branches in [[Rockhampton]] and [[Gympie]], and by 1873 it had expanded into the areas of tailoring, furniture, furnishing, and hardware.
in 1879, Finney pioneered 6 p.m. closing in Brisbane stores. In 1885, with other firms, he instituted 1 p.m. closing on Saturdays and even after other firms reverted to the old Saturday hours of 8 a.m. to 11 p.m, Finney continued it. A charity fund of the employees was subsidized £ for £ by the management and was administered by a committee that included the managing director and two employees elected by the staff.
The business suffered severely in 1893 from flood waters and from the financial crisis, but soon recovered.
At some point Finney was elected to the Toowong Shire Council, and in 1896 he won the [[electoral district of Toowong]] and was seated in the [[Legislative Assembly of Queensland]], holding his seat until his resignation in 1902.
Finney was married thrice. On 22 May 1864, he was wed to Kate Pringle Little, but she died after two years and he married Sidney Anne Jackson, whose sister married Finney’s business partner, James Isles. Finney and Sidney had two daughters and a son together, and she died on 13 October 1883. In 1901, while in England, Finney married Janet Edgar Farrow, a widow.
He died on 16 December 1903 and was buried in [[Toowong Cemetery]].<ref name=bcc>[https://online.brisbane.qld.gov.au/cemeteries/cemeteries_step3.jsp?mapdisplay=142585 Finney Thomas] — Brisbane City Council Grave Location Search. Retrieved 26 January 2015.</ref>

{{Coord|55|46|N|37|36|E|type:adm2nd_source:kolossus-ruwiki|display=title}} [[File:Msk cao tverskoy.png|thumb|Tverskoy and [[Kitai-gorod]] on the map of Moscow. As of 2007, Kitai-gorod is a separate territory governed directly by Central Administrative Okrug]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Tverskoy (municipality in Moscow).png|thumb|Coat of arms of Tverskoy District]]
'''Tverskoy District''' ({{lang-rus|Тверско́й райо́н|p=tvʲɪrˈskoj|a=Ru-Тверской.ogg}}) is a [[administrative divisions of Moscow|district]] of [[Central Administrative Okrug]] of the [[federal cities of Russia|federal city]] of [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. Population: {{ru-census2010|75,378|;}} {{ru-census2002|75,955|.}}
The district extends from [[Kitai-gorod]] northwest to [[Belorussky Rail Terminal|Belorussky]] and [[Savyolovsky Rail Terminal]]s . Its southern boundary runs one or two city blocks south from [[Tverskaya Street]]; eastern boundary follows the track of the [[Neglinnaya River]] now flowing in a [[tunnel]] under Samotechnaya Street, [[Tsvetnoy Boulevard]], and Neglinnaya Street.
Tverskoy District houses [[State Duma]], [[Federation Council of Russia|Federation Council]], the Mayor of Moscow, Moscow City Council, and [[Moscow Police]] Headquarters. It contains [[Theatre Square]], the business district of Tverskaya Street with [[Pushkin Square]], [[Petrovka Street]], Dmitrovka Street, and the western part of [[Kuznetsky Most]]. It has the highest concentration of theatres, including [[Bolshoi Theatre]] and the historical Pillar Hall of the [[House of the Unions]].
Historical areas of [[Patriarshy Ponds]], Malaya Bronnaya Street, and most of [[Tverskoy Boulevard]], while closely associated with Tverskaya Street actually belong to [[Presnensky District]]. Since 2002 Tverskoy District also includes [[Kitai-gorod]], which was once a separate territory managed directly by Central Administrative Okrug.
==History== ''This section is based on P. V. Sytin's "History of Moscow Streets"''<ref>Russian: П.В.Сытин, "Из истории московских улиц", М, 1948 (''Sytin'')</ref>
===Old Muscovy to 19th century=== [[File:Vysokopetrovsky Monastery 6.JPG|thumb|St. Peter's Cathedral, Vysokopetrovsky Monastery, ca. 1508]]
Tverskaya Street emerged, as the road to [[Tver]], in the 12th century. Dmitrovka Street, the road to [[Dmitrov]], and [[Petrovka Street]], leading to [[Vysokopetrovsky Monastery]], date back to the 14th century.
[[File:Putinki.jpg|thumb|left|Church of Nativity in Putinki, 1650s]]
Until the 1820s, the territory of what is now Tverskoy District was separated from the [[Moscow Kremlin]] by the [[Neglinnaya River]]. Because of that, the city grew primarily eastward in the Middle Ages—into the [[Red Square]] and Kitai-Gorod—while the development of western territories lagged behind. A stone bridge connecting Tverskaya with the Red Square was built in 1595. Urban development in the western part concentrated along Tverskaya Street. In the late 15th century, it was built out with country-like wooden homes to Pushkin Square, and by the end of the 16th century the city extended beyond the present-day [[Garden Ring]]. First stone [[Boyar]] houses appeared in downtown Tverskaya around that time. In 1654, [[Strastnoy Monastery]] was set up in present-day Pushkin Square, and three years later, Odoyevsky family set up a stone mansion on the site of present-day Museum of Modern History (formerly Museum of Revolution), beyond the [[Bely Gorod]] walls.
[[File:Dmitrovka Street, 2010192.jpg|thumb|Dmitrovka Street]]
Dmitrovka Street also developed rapidly after the fire of 1648, as marked by the one-of-a-kind eight-[[tented church]] of [[Nativity Church at Putinki|Nativity in Putinki]]. Unusually for Moscow outskirts, it was financed by the State, as the church was located near the Embassy Inn ({{lang|ru|Посольский двор}}), home to foreign guests.<ref>''Sytin'', p.190</ref>
[[File:Dmitrovka Street, 2010193.jpg|thumb|left|Dmitrovka Street]]
[[Peter the Great]]'s move of the national [[capital (political)|capital]] to [[Saint Petersburg]] actually improved the leading role of Tverskaya Street, as it became the main road of royal journeys between two capitals. Tverskaya acquired Moscow's first triumphal arch (1703, giving name to Triumphalnaya Square), [[Gagarin family]] palace (1760s), and [[Zakhar Chernyshyov]] mansion (1782); later the seat of Moscow Governor, [[Mossovet]], and currently of the Mayor of Moscow (which was rebuilt in the 1940s). The [[Fire of Moscow (1812)|Fire of 1812]] wiped out wealthy mansions and peasant homes alike, sparing only the Pushkin Square;<ref>''Sytin'', p.128</ref> Tverskaya was rebuilt as an upper-class street and retained this status ever since.
Northeastern side of Tverskoy District (east of Petrovka Street) lagged behind Tverskaya Street and Moscow's east side due to frequent floods on the Neglinnaya River. First attempt to control the river, proposed in 1775 by Matvey Kazakov, materialized in 1792 Neglinnaya Canal, which was running parallel to the river. Once the canal was completed, the old river bed was filled with earth. In 1817–1819, the channel was covered with masonry vaults, locking the stream in an underground tunnel. This created Neglinnaya Street, the youngest street inside Boulevard Ring, but did not rule out future floods. The most recent flood, in 1973, led to complete rebuilding of the aging tunnel (1974–1989, see [http://www.mosinzhproekt.ru/press-center/articles/print_neglinka.shtml 1965 flood photos])<ref>Russian, Contractor report: Река Неглинная. История и современность, Мосинжроект, 2005 [http://www.mosinzhproekt.ru/press-center/articles/print_neglinka.shtml www.mosinzhproekt.ru]</ref> Another legacy of the Neglinnaya river survives in Central Baths (1890) and [[Sanduny|Sandunovsky Baths]] (1896).<ref>Russian: "Москва начала века", М, ООО "O-Мастер", 2001 {{ISBN|5-9207-0001-7}} стр.184 (''Builders of Moscow'', p.184). Dates are for extant buildings. Sandunov family owned the baths since the 18th century.</ref><ref>Sandunovsky Baths on Neglinnays Street are actually located in [[Meshchansky District]] (on the eastern side of the street), just like the [[Central Bank of Russian Federation]] building.</ref>
====Theatre District==== [[File:MosMetro Teatralnaya img3 asv2018-01.jpg|thumb|Theatre Square, Teatralnaya metro station]]
The first public theater, ''[[Petrovka Theatre|Petrovsky Teatr]]'', was set up in 1780 by English entrepreneur [[Michael Maddox]] and Prince Urusov in present-day [[Theatre Square]]. It burned down in October 1805 after 425 successful shows.<ref>German: [http://russlandonline.ru/bolschoi/morenews.php?iditem=27 http://russlandonline.ru]</ref> In 1825, [[Joseph Bove]] built a new, larger [[Bolshoi Theatre]] on the same site. By this time, downtown stretch of the Neglinnaya River was contained in an underground tunnel; Peter's [[bastion]]s of Kitai-gorod were razed, forming the [[Theatre Square]]. In the same 1825, landowner Vargin built Maly Theatre on his own adjacent lot. For the first five years, the State leased the building from Vargin; he was later convicted of fraud and the State bought out the building in 1832.<ref>''Builders of Moscow'', p.184</ref> Owners of the opposite land lots were obliged to build houses exactly like Maly Theatre, forming a perfectly symmetrical [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]] square with a parade ground and water fountain. The symmetry was eventually ruined by expansions in the 1870s, which added the third theatre—originally Bronnikov private theater (now Molodyozhny Theater).
Another historical hall, the Assembly of Nobility (now the [[House of the Unions]]) stands on the corner of Bolshaya Dmitrovka and [[Okhotny Ryad (street)|Okhotny Ryad]] streets since 1790. The building, designed by [[Matvey Kazakov]], was rebuilt externally, but the Pillar Hall inside it, famous for its [[acoustics]], remains close to Kazakov's original design. When the State lifted the ban on private theatres in 1882, tradition continued with [[Moscow Art Theatre]] in Kamergersky Lane (1902–1909),<ref>''Builders of Russia'', p.187 says "minor construction work proceeded till 1909". Substantial completion is usually dated 1903</ref> [[Yermolova Theatre]] (1925), Hermitage (1883), and Aquarium (1898) park theatres, etc. Currently, Tverskoy District has nineteen [[repertory]] theatres, the Pillar Hall, [[Tchaikovsky]] Hall (1940), and [[Moscow Circus on Tsvetnoy Boulevard]] (originally Salamonovsky Circus, 1880, rebuilt in 1987–1989).
====Industrial expansion==== [[File:Wiki Zelenko Kindergarten Vadkovsky Lane.jpg|thumb|1907 Communal Club for working teenagers, funded by [[Nikolai Krotov (industrialist)|Nikolay Krotov]], designed and managed by [[Alexander Zelenko]] and [[Stanislav Shatsky]]]]
Unlike [[Presnensky District|Presnensky]] or [[Basmanny District]]s, Tverskoy has, and always had, very few industrial properties. However, its northern part, beyond Garden Ring, developed into a working-class neighborhood in line with the 19th-century industrialization. Development began in the 18th century with the [[Butyrka prison]] (rebuilt to a castle shape in 1800).<ref>''Builders of Moscow'', p.42</ref> For the next hundred years, the territories around the prison were filled with farms and small wooden homes. Things changed with the construction of railroads—[[Smolensk]] railroad station was built in 1870; current building, known as [[Belorussky Rail Terminal]], was completed in 1909. [[Savyolovsky Rail Terminal]] and Moscow Ring Railroad followed in the 1900s. Territories near the railroads were quickly used for factories, cheap housing for workers followed soon.
Miusskaya Square, located three blocks from Belorussky Terminal, was a site of unusual urban development, a new center of blue-collar social life. In the course of one decade, 1904–1914, the city and private sponsors built Abrikosova Hospital and Nursery (1906),<ref>''Builders of Moscow'', p.329</ref> Junior High School (1912),<ref>''Builders of Moscow'', p.372</ref> Shanyavsky University (1913),<ref>''Builders of Moscow'', p.382</ref> kindergartens, and trade schools. Development of similar social hubs in other working districts lagged behind and terminated with [[World War I]] and [[Russian Revolution of 1917]].
====Modern history==== [[File:Corner of Manege Square, Moscow.jpg|thumb|left|Corner of [[Manezhnaya Square, Moscow|Manege Square]]: extant National Hotel and demolished Intourist Hotel (1970–2002)]]
Redevelopment of Tverskaya Street began in the late 1920s with infill buildings like [[Ivan Rerberg]]'s Central Telegraph (1927), and [[Grigory Barkhin]]'s [[Izvestia]] building in Pushkin Square (1927). This was followed by demolition of [[Okhotny Ryad (street)|Okhotny Ryad]] and [[Manezhnaya Square, Moscow|Manege Square]].
Major reconstruction of Tverskaya Street began in 1937 with demolition of Strastnoy Monastery and dozens of smaller buildings. Three buildings, including Savvinskoye Podvorye, [[Mossovet]] building, and the Eye Clinic, were spared from demolition and moved to new foundations farther from the street. As a result, Savvinskoye Podvorye is now completely locked inside a 1930s [[stalinist architecture|stalinist]] block. Another building, a print shop at Pushkin Square, was moved in the 1970s to make way for Izvestia expansion.<ref>М.Трубилина, "Переезды во сне и наяву", Российская Газета, 1 марта 2004, [http://www.rg.ru/2004/03/01/pereezdy.html www.rg.ru]</ref>
Design of the first stretch of new Gorky Street (the name of Tverskaya since 1935) was awarded to [[Arkady Mordvinov]], 1929 graduate in architecture known for his ultra-left public statements. Mordvinov proved himself a good project manager, successfully testing so-called ''flow method'' of fast-track construction. By 1941, most of central Gorky Street was completed; the rest was built out after [[World War II]].
[[File:Wiki St Nicholas u Tverskoy.jpg|thumb|Contemporary [[Old Believers]] murals near Belorussky Terminal<ref>St.Nicholas church of [[Rogozhskoye Cemetery|Rogozhskoye Old Believers]] was laid down shortly before [[World War I]] and was not properly completed and consecrated before the Revolution of 1917. All exterior and interior finished were made from scratch in the 1990s.</ref>]]
In the 1970s, the street acquired [[Leonid Brezhnev|Brezhnev]]-era boxlike buildings of 23-story [[Intourist]] Hotel (1970, demolished in 2002<ref>Russian: illustrated contractor's report on demolition [http://www.krealist.ru/showinfo.php?id=50 www.krealist.ru]</ref>) and smaller Minsk Hotel (1964, demolished in 2005) and New Izvestia building; less controversial pseudo-stalinist infill buildings followed in the 1980s and late 1990s. However, outside Tverskaya, historical buildings and neighborhoods were being demolished throughout the 1990s and 2000s. Many blocks in the [[Novoslobodskaya]] station area are already rebuilt as post-2000 highrises. The City has declared plans to reconstruct Pushkin Square and Belorussky Terminal Square with mult-level underground tunnels, shopping space, and parking<ref>English: Pushkin Square Under Threat, The Moscow Times, 24.10.2006 [http://www.maps-moscow.com/index.php?chapter_id=149&data_id=229&do=view_single MAPS] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070515055542/http://www.maps-moscow.com/index.php?chapter_id=149&data_id=229&do=view_single |date=May 15, 2007 }}</ref>, but those plans were later abolished with mayor resignation.
Population of Tverskoy District is traditionally affluent and educated, with a substantial share of foreigners (most of them are not included in official population count). Its ethnic mix, changing rapidly since the 1980s, has high shares of [[Tatars]], [[Armenians]] and [[Jews]]; once-strong [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] community has dispersed.<ref>Russian: Ethnicity maps in: Вендина, Ольга (ред.) Москва этническая: грозит ли городу геттоизация? "Население и общество", 2004, N177 [http://www.demoscope.ru/weekly/2004/0177/tema03.php www.demoscope.ru]</ref> Like all Central Okrug population, Tverskoy residents have life expectancy of three to four years higher than other Muscovites, attributed to better education and social status.<ref>Russian: Mortality map: Игнатова, Ольга "Ближе к центру — дольше жизнь. Продолжительность жизни в столице увеличилась на 9 лет", "Российская газета", 19.02.2007 [http://www.rg.ru/2007/02/19/moskva-jizn.html www.rg.ru]</ref>
==Government and infrastructure== The [[Ministry of Education and Science (Russia)|Ministry of Education and Science]] has its head office in the district.<ref>"[http://eng.mon.gov.ru/obr/cont/ CONTACT] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115062101/http://eng.mon.gov.ru/obr/cont/ |date=November 15, 2011 }}." Ministry of Education and Science. Retrieved on 1 November 2011. "''Address'': Tverskaya street, 11, Moscow, 125993" - [http://mon.gov.ru/obr/kont/ Address in Russian] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105050338/http://mon.gov.ru/obr/kont/ |date=November 5, 2011 }}: "ул.Тверская, д.11, г.Москва, ГСП-3, 125993"</ref> For their role in the [[Sergei Magnitsky]] case, several judges of the Tverskoy [[Judiciary of Russia#District courts|District Court]] are subject to the American [[Magnitsky Act]] sanctions,<ref>{{cite news|title=Magnitsky List release: severe blow on Moscow-US ties|date=12 April 2013|work=[[Voice of Russia]]|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2013_04_12/Magnitsky-List-release-severe-blow-on-Moscow-US-ties/}}</ref> prohibiting their entrance to the United States and use of the US banking system.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/us-passes-magnitsky-bill-aimed-at-russia/2012/12/06/262a5bba-3fd5-11e2-bca3-aadc9b7e29c5_story.html|title=Russia fumes as U.S. Senate passes Magnitsky law aimed at human rights|date=6 December 2012|accessdate=11 December 2012|work=[[The Washington Post]]|first1=Kathy|last1=Lally|first2=Will|last2=Englund}}</ref>
==Economy== [[Korean Air]] operates its CIS office in the district.<ref>"[http://www.koreanair.com/local/ru/ld/eng/au/ci/eng_au_ci.jsp Company Info / Contact Info]." [[Korean Air]]. Retrieved on 30 August 2011. "CIS Headquarters Bolshoy Gnezdnykovsky Pereulok D1/2, Moscow, Russia" [http://www.koreanair.com/local/ru/ld/rus/au/ci/rus_au_ci.jsp Address in Russian]: "Большой Гнездниковский переулок 1/2 Москва Россия"</ref>
